subSections.title: Glyph origin
Etymology 1
subSections.text:
Possibly from {{der|zh|sit}}. 

{{zh-ref|Benedict, 1972}}, {{zh-ref|Schuessler, 2007}}, and STEDT relate this to {{cog|tbq-pro|*g-nam||sky, sun}}; the south is traditionally associated with the sun & light, compare {{och-l|[[陽]]|light, sun-lit south-side of a hill}}. If so, cognate with {{cog|bo|གནམ||sky}}, {{m|bo|ནམ||night}}, {{cog|tsj|ngam||sun, noon, day, sky}}, {{cog|cdm|tr=nyam|t=sun, sunlight, storm-cloud, weather}}.

Alternatively, {{zh-ref|Sagart (2004)}} relates this to {{cog|tbq-pro|*s-nam||rib(s)}}, as one term for one body-part often shifts its meaning to another body-part nearby; Sagart considers  Proto-Tibeto-Burman *''nam'' a cognate with Old Chinese *''nɨm'' (revised to *''nˤ[ə]m'' in 2014) "belly, front of the body", further "south". 
:If so, 南 is cognate with  {{och-l|[[妊]]|to carry inside one's belly → to be pregnant}}, {{och-l|任|to carry a burden, especially in front of the body}}, also {{och-l|[[腩]]|belly (of an ox)}}, {{cog|pmj|nõ⁵⁵}}, {{cog|my|tr=nam|t=side of the body, rib}}, and thus is a semantic counterpart to {{och-l|[[北]]|north}}, which is related to {{och-l|[[背]]|back of the body}}.
